message.content:
We need to “pull out” from the table only those cash‐flow transactions that change the firm’s long‐term (investment) balances. In a typical cash flow statement the “investing activities” are the cash used to acquire (or cash received on sale of) noncurrent assets. (Often a “fixed‐asset” purchase is separately recorded.) In the example provided the only investing activity was the purchase of a fixed asset (the “Fixed Assets Purchase” which produced a cash outflow of 305354.43).

In the current problem the only “nonoperating” (that is, “investing”) cash flows come from the purchase transactions that result in an “Enterprise Solution” – a product that (by its name and classification in our sample data) is taken to be a capital item. (The “Basic Consulting”, “Standard Consulting” and “Premium Consulting” items are small‐ticket, “operating” items; and the “Initial” entries – even the “Fixed Assets” line – are opening‐balance entries rather than actual cash flows.) 

Looking over the “Purchase” transactions we must include only those which (a) are for a product called “Enterprise Solution” and (b) were paid (i.e. cash actually “paid”). In our table these are:

• Purchase20231231001 (type “Purchase”) has product “Enterprise Solution”, an amount of 300000.0, payment status “Paid” (by Bank Transfer).

• Purchase20231231003 (type “Purchase”) has product “Enterprise Solution”, an amount of 300000.0, payment status “Paid” (by Cash).

• Purchase20231231005 (type “Purchase”) has product “Enterprise Solution”, an amount of 200000.0, payment status “Paid”.

• Purchase20231231009 – although it is for “Enterprise Solution” with an amount of 200000.0 – its payment/receipt status is “Unpaid” so no cash has “left” the company yet.

• Purchase20231231010 – another “Enterprise Solution” purchase with an amount of 200000.0 is also “Unpaid.”

• Purchase20231231011 (type “Purchase”) has product “Enterprise Solution”, an amount of 200000.0, and is “Paid.”

• Purchase20231231012 (type “Purchase”) has product “Enterprise Solution”, an amount of 200000.0, “Paid.”

Only the “Paid” ones produce an actual cash outflow. (All the other “Purchase” lines – such as those whose product is “Basic Consulting,” “Standard Consulting” or “Premium Consulting” – are treated as operating expense purchases.) 

Now add up the amounts for the “Enterprise Solution” purchases that are paid:

 300000.0 
+ 300000.0 
+ 200000.0 
+ 200000.0 (from Purchase20231231011)
+ 200000.0 (from Purchase20231231012)
——————————————–
 = 1200000.0

Since cash was paid out (an outflow) the net effect of investing activities is negative:

Net Cash Flow from Investing Activities = –1200000.0

Thus, the final answer is:

{
  "solution": {"Net Cash Flow from Investing Activities": "-1200000.0"}
}
